item.title: They Helped Women Fight Online Abuse. They Were Barred From the U.S.
item.content:encoded: The founders of HateAid, a German human-rights group that helps victims of online attacks, were accused by the Trump administration of being part of a “global censorship-industrial complex.”

item.title: The Economy Is a Feeling
item.content:encoded: Today, we’re looking at how politicians are framing affordability.

item.title: How a Close Associate of Epstein’s Found Career Redemption in Japan
item.content:encoded: Top Japanese officials are backing a tech and entrepreneurship initiative led by Joichi Ito, whose involvement with Jeffrey Epstein may endanger efforts to get the project off the ground.

item.title: How a Close Associate of Epstein’s Found Career Redemption in Japan
item.content:encoded: Top Japanese officials are backing a tech and entrepreneurship initiative led by Joichi Ito, whose involvement with Jeffrey Epstein may endanger efforts to get the project off the ground.

item.title: Why Are So Many Democrats Running for California Governor?
item.content:encoded: With California’s political machine on the wane, nobody has emerged as a clear front-runner. Democrats worry that nine of their candidates could split the vote and hand Republicans a win.

item.title: New A.C.A. Plans Could Increase Family Deductibles to $31,000
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration is proposing Obamacare plans that it says will lower health insurance premiums. But critics warn they would make care unaffordable.

item.title: New A.C.A. Plans Could Increase Family Deductibles to $31,000
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration is proposing Obamacare plans that it says will lower health insurance premiums. But critics warn they would make care unaffordable.

item.title: Kalshi Accuses a ‘MrBeast’ Employee of Insider Trading
item.content:encoded: The prediction-market platform said it had reported the employee to federal regulators. The show’s parent company said it had “no tolerance for this behavior.”

item.title: Man Arrested in New York Snowball Fight That Police Said Injured Officers
item.content:encoded: The incident, which began as a playful event, shifted in tone when the police appeared. Mayor Zohran Mamdani has said it did not appear to be a crime, while other officials called for arrests.

item.title: Russia Launches Big Strikes Before U.S.-Ukraine Talks in Geneva
item.content:encoded: Moscow unleashed an extensive drone and missile attack just hours before American officials met with Kyiv’s chief negotiator.

item.title: World Economic Forum Chief Resigns Over Epstein Ties
item.content:encoded: Borge Brende, a former foreign minister of Norway, had maintained contact with the convicted sex offender.

item.title: World Economic Forum Chief Resigns Over Epstein Ties
item.content:encoded: Borge Brende, a former foreign minister of Norway, had maintained contact with the convicted sex offender.

item.title: How A.I.-Generated Videos Are Distorting Your Child’s YouTube Feed
item.content:encoded: Experts caution that low-quality, A.I.-generated videos on YouTube geared toward children often feature conflicting information, lack plot structure and can be cognitively overwhelming — all of which could affect young children’s development.

item.title: He Hopes to Turn the Island of Nevis Into a Libertarian Paradise, With Crypto
item.content:encoded: A Bitcoin baron wants to build a libertarian paradise on the island of Nevis. Democracy is getting in the way.

item.title: How Israelis Feel About Another Potential War With Iran
item.content:encoded: The national mood is somewhere between anxiety, resignation and anticipation as President Trump considers whether to attack Iran.

item.title: Bright Horizons Let Some Staff Work Without Full Vetting, Records Show
item.content:encoded: Inspectors found several instances in which child care staff members were working in classrooms even though they had not completed all of the required background checks.

item.title: The Trumpiest Trump We’ve Ever Beheld
item.content:encoded: The president is becoming the very thing that destroyed the Democrats: a reality-denying machine.

item.title: Why Nvidia’s Big Profits Aren’t Lifting Markets
item.content:encoded: The chip giant at the center of the artificial intelligence boom again beat expectations. But it didn’t overcome investor jitters.

item.title: Why Nvidia’s Big Profits Aren’t Lifting Markets
item.content:encoded: The chip giant at the center of the artificial intelligence boom again beat expectations. But it didn’t overcome investor jitters.

item.title: Revel, a Maker of Software for Running Hardware, Raises $150 Million
item.content:encoded: The start-up, founded by a former top SpaceX engineer, promises to help companies reduce their testing times and optimize systems.

item.title: A.I. Dating Apps Complicate China’s Efforts to Boost Birthrate
item.content:encoded: As China grapples with a shrinking population and historically low birthrate, people are finding romance with chatbots instead.

item.title: What We Know About the Gun Battle Off the Coast of Cuba
item.content:encoded: Four armed Cubans aboard a Florida-based speedboat died in a gunfight with Cuban border troops on Wednesday, officials said.

item.title: China Wants Germany in Its Corner. It’s Not That Easy.
item.content:encoded: China’s play for U.S. allies has a problem: As Germany’s leader showed, Europe’s grievances with Beijing may run deeper than its frustration with Trump.

item.title: The Secret of How Ukraine’s Lifesaving Air-Raid Alarms Work
item.content:encoded: Many in Ukraine assume that the alerts are automated. A rare look inside an emergency-response center reveals the specialists who do the pressure-packed job.

item.title: The Missing Records From the Epstein Files, and a Gun Battle Off the Coast of Cuba
item.content:encoded: Plus, a big shift in the housing market.

item.title: When Chatbots Are Used to Plan Violence, Is There a Duty to Warn?
item.content:encoded: People are revealing sensitive personal information to A.I. chatbots — including plans to commit violent acts.

item.title: Antarctica’s Mineral Riches Exposed as Climate Warms
item.content:encoded: Mining is banned on the frozen continent. But new research suggests that could change as ice melts and land and valuable minerals are exposed.

item.title: A.I. Complicates Old Internet Privacy Risks
item.content:encoded: Artificial intelligence is convenient and easy to use, but you should think about what you say to the chatbots.

item.title: Z? Zo? Mam? Mayor Zohran Mamdani is a Man of Many Nicknames.
item.content:encoded: Mayor Zohran Mamdani has been given a bevy of nicknames by New York City’s tabloid newspapers and political class. Which will stick?

item.title: Z? Zo? Mam? Mayor Zohran Mamdani is a Man of Many Nicknames.
item.content:encoded: Mayor Zohran Mamdani has been given a bevy of nicknames by New York City’s tabloid newspapers and political class. Which will stick?

item.title: ‘Grease 2,’ the Giddy, Raunchy Flop That Brought Us Michelle Pfeiffer
item.content:encoded: The highly anticipated 1982 sequel failed to meet expectations at the time but has since charmed an adoring following with its ambitions dance numbers and nonstop ear worms.

item.title: Why Are So Many Teen Girls Still Tearing Their A.C.L.s?
item.content:encoded: For years, ligament tears have been a crisis among young athletes — even though a few simple exercises can prevent them.

item.title: Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders’s Plan to Build a Prison in Arkansas Divides GOP
item.content:encoded: Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders wants to build a huge, pricey prison to hold the inmates incarcerated under her tough-on-crime agenda, and she hopes to oust fellow Republicans on Tuesday to do it.

item.title: Late Night Fixates on How Long Trump Spoke
item.content:encoded: “This time, Trump spoke and everyone else fell asleep,” Jimmy Fallon said.

item.title: President Emmanuel Macron’s Cultural Legacy At Risk After Louvre Chief Resigns
item.content:encoded: President Emmanuel Macron has championed a refurbishment of the museum, but the fallout from a sensational heist has put his plans at risk.

item.title: For Trump, Military Strike in Iran Could Serve Symbolic Purpose
item.content:encoded: Some officials in the Trump administration hope an attack would force Iran to give up its nuclear enrichment program. Others have doubts.

item.title: The Gorton and Denton By-Election Comes at a Bad Time for Keir Starmer
item.content:encoded: A parliamentary by-election in Gorton and Denton, outside Manchester, will test support for Britain’s prime minister at a moment of intense political pressure.

item.title: Patel Fires F.B.I. Personnel Tied to Inquiry Into Trump and Classified Records
item.content:encoded: The firings are part of a rolling barrage of retribution aimed at those who worked on the two federal prosecutions of President Trump.

item.title: Trump’s Push for Election Power Raises Fears He Will ‘Subvert’ Midterms
item.content:encoded: The president appears to be undermining Americans’ faith in the outcome, at a moment when Republicans face an uphill climb to keep control of Congress.

item.title: Bleak Research Report Stokes A.I. Debate on Wall St.
item.content:encoded: In a widely circulated note, Citrini Research painted a dire picture of job losses and stock market sell-offs, though many analysts and economists questioned its conclusions.

item.title: Trump Proposed a New Retirement Plan for With Up to a $1,000 Match. What to Know.
item.content:encoded: An existing law could help create new retirement savings plans for people who lack them. But there may be income restrictions on any match.

item.title: Businesses Push for Tariff Refunds as Trump Aides Hint at Fight to Come
item.content:encoded: By the president’s own admission, it could be years before the matter is settled, even though the administration previously indicated it would pay.

item.title: For America’s 250th, Should the Coin of Trump’s Realm Be Gold?
item.content:encoded: A federally appointed committee is pushing back on plans to mint gold currency depicting President Trump.

item.title: Blaming Tariffs, Aston Martin Will Trim 20% of Its Work Force
item.content:encoded: The luxury automaker said losses for 2025 had increased from the year before, as tariffs and geopolitical uncertainty took a toll on its operations.

item.title: With Epstein Deposition, Hillary Clinton Is Again Answering for Bill Clinton’s Actions
item.content:encoded: The former first lady, senator and secretary of state had no dealings with Jeffrey Epstein but is once again under pressure to answer for the actions and relationships of her husband.

item.title: Abu Dhabi’s State Oil Company Looks Beyond Oil
item.content:encoded: Having reshaped the company, Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber wants to expand internationally, particularly in natural gas, chemicals and renewables.

item.title: Corporate America’s Growing Quest for Tariff Refunds
item.content:encoded: Thousands of companies are expected to follow FedEx in suing the government to recoup levy payments, after the Supreme Court overturned the tariffs.

item.title: What Trump Did (and Didn’t) Say in the State of the Union Speech
item.content:encoded: The president boasted about a strong economy in his State of the Union address. But he spent less time on a potential weakness, affordability.

item.title: From the French Riviera to Kyoto, Japan, 5 New Luxury Hotels
item.content:encoded: From palatial to contemporary to luxuriously rustic, this collection of new resorts and inns offers spas, private gardens, fine restaurants and exquisite settings.

item.title: Pentagon Gives Anthropic an Ultimatum Over the Company’s A.I. Model
item.content:encoded: Anthropic insists on limits on how its technology is used and could be labeled a supply chain risk if it fails to accept the military’s demands.

item.title: Court Rules Against Justice Dept. Search of Reporter’s Computers
item.content:encoded: The judge said the court itself would search the devices, which were seized from a Washington Post reporter’s home last month.

item.title: Paramount Raises Its Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.content:encoded: Warner Bros. Discovery said Paramount’s new offer of $31 a share could lead to a “superior proposal” to the deal it signed with Netflix.

item.title: Senator Blumenthal Opens Inquiry Into Iran Transactions on Binance
item.content:encoded: Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut sent a letter to Binance asking about the flow of $1.7 billion from accounts on the crypto exchange to Iranian entities.

item.title: Wayve, an A.I. Driverless Car Start-Up in Europe, Raises $1.2 Billion
item.content:encoded: The London-based company is building a system that uses artificial intelligence to power autonomous vehicles.

item.title: Averted Midair Collision Shows Importance of Air Safety Act, Backers Say
item.content:encoded: The legislation’s advocates say a close call between two private planes near Teterboro, N.J., on Feb. 13 underscored how collision prevention technology could save lives.

item.title: House Narrowly Rejects Air Safety Bill After Pentagon Opposition
item.content:encoded: A move to swiftly pass the bill failed by a single vote. It would have required aircraft to carry technology that officials said might have prevented a midair collision near Washington last year.

item.title: U.K., Australia and Others Worse Off Under Trump’s New Tariffs
item.content:encoded: Many important U.S. trading partners are facing higher duties after President Trump, reacting to a Supreme Court setback, set the rate on a new set of global tariffs at 15 percent.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Are Adding Steel Mill Jobs, and Crushing American Factories
item.content:encoded: Tariffs unaffected by President Trump’s Supreme Court loss are adding costs for many U.S. manufacturers that use steel, limiting exports and jeopardizing jobs.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Go Into Effect at 10 Percent, Not 15
item.content:encoded: The change surprised executives and foreign leaders, who had been expecting the 15 percent rate the president announced on Saturday.

item.title: Trump’s New Tariffs Could Face Legal Challenges
item.content:encoded: Critics are questioning the legality of the provision President Trump has used to replace his previous slate of tariffs, raising the prospect of yet another legal battle.

item.title: More Than Half of Teens Use Chatbots for Schoolwork, Survey Finds
item.content:encoded: A new study from the Pew Research Center finds teenagers think chatbot-assisted cheating has become “a regular feature of student life.”

item.title: Home Depot Says Homeowners Are Weary From Economic Pressures
item.content:encoded: The retailer said same-store sales were nearly flat as homeowners shied away from big-ticket projects amid worries about housing costs and the job market.

item.title: Racing to Catch Up With Nvidia, AMD Signs Chips-for-Stock Deal With Meta
item.content:encoded: The multibillion-dollar deal is AMD’s latest move to catch up to Nvidia in the lucrative world of selling artificial intelligence chips.

item.title: The Looming Taiwan Chip Disaster That Silicon Valley Has Long Ignored
item.content:encoded: If China invades Taiwan and cuts off its chip exports to American companies, the tech industry and the U.S. economy would be crippled.

item.title: What’s Happened Since the Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.content:encoded: After the Trump administration’s punishing tariffs were invalidated, the president said he would impose new tariffs using a different authority. It’s been a whirlwind.

item.title: Trump Officials Seek to ‘Reimagine’ Unemployment Benefits, Targeting Fraud
item.content:encoded: Federal officials are subjecting some states to higher scrutiny in an antifraud campaign, as the president rails against California and states led by Democrats.

item.title: Supreme Court Sides With Couple in Case Involving Baby Food Sold at Whole Foods
item.content:encoded: The court agreed to revive a lawsuit by a Texas couple who claimed that tainted baby food purchased at Whole Foods had sickened their young son.

item.title: Paramount Revises Its Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.content:encoded: If Warner Bros. deems Paramount’s latest bid superior, Netflix would have four days to make a counteroffer.

item.title: Storm Leads to a First for The Boston Globe: A Day Without a Paper
item.content:encoded: The company said the blizzard had made it too treacherous for workers to make it to the printing press on Monday.

item.title: After Saks Bankruptcy, Richard Baker Says He Saved Luxury Department Stores
item.content:encoded: Richard Baker wanted to create a retail empire when he combined Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus. About a year later, it filed for bankruptcy.

item.title: I.R.S. Tactics Against Meta Open a New Front in the Corporate Tax Fight
item.content:encoded: The agency is using real-world profit data to challenge how big companies value offshore intellectual property.

item.title: FedEx Sues for Refund of Trump Tariffs Rejected by Supreme Court
item.content:encoded: The company, which did not specify how much it was seeking, is expected to be one of many demanding compensation for levies ruled unlawful.

item.title: Pentagon Summons Anthropic Chief in Dispute Over A.I. Limits
item.content:encoded: The artificial intelligence company has demanded that some guardrails be put in place as it negotiates a contract with the Defense Department.

item.title: Trump Administration Scrambles to Pick Up the Pieces of Broken Tariffs
item.content:encoded: President Trump is already working to piece his tariff program back together, after a Supreme Court ruling ruptured a centerpiece of his economic agenda.

item.title: Thousands of Flights Are Canceled as Storm Slams Northeast Airports
item.content:encoded: Airlines suspended operations at some major airports and expect to restart some flights on Monday and more on Tuesday.

item.title: Binance Employees Find $1.7 Billion in Crypto Was Sent to Iranian Entities
item.content:encoded: Binance pledged to crack down on crime. But internal investigators at the world’s largest crypto exchange continued to find evidence of potential legal violations on the platform.

item.title: Top Fed Official Sees Little Effect on Rate Outlook From Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.content:encoded: Christopher J. Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, said he would support a pause in rate cuts in March if the labor market continued to show signs of stabilizing.

item.title: More Than Half a Million Customers Have Lost Power on East Coast
item.content:encoded: The outages were mostly caused by problems with local power lines, and coastal Massachusetts was particularly hard hit.

item.title: Tariff Turmoil Returns to Global Markets
item.content:encoded: Businesses and U.S. trade partners are again grappling with the uncertainty of President Trump’s trade war, even as he imposes new levies.
